awd_titl_txt: CICI: RSARC: Trustworthy Computing over Protected Datasets
awd_abstract_narration:
Scientists are often stymied in their research due to the inaccessibility of relevant data. Additionally, many data owners silo data away from powerful, economical cloud computing resources due to privacy and confidentiality concerns. This project enables data scientists to compute statistics over protected datasets while simultaneously empowering the owners of the underlying datasets to maintain control over how their data is used in computations and viewed by other people. The work also brings a cryptographically secure computing engine to one of the largest collections of small to medium sized research data in the world, running on a federated datacenter operated by multiple non-trusting vendors. In doing so, this project enhances the flow of information sharing to promote transparency and accountability for data sharing and processing decisions while simultaneously reducing tenants' need to trust the cloud's behavior thanks to cryptographic protections that promote confidentiality and integrity. The project enables scientific research computing on workflows involving collaborative experiments or replication and extension of existing results when the underlying data are encumbered by privacy concerns.

To accomplish this goal and enhance the economic potential of the cloud, the researchers and engineers on this project integrate and enhance three technologies they have previously developed. First, the Dataverse data management infrastructure houses, curates, and indexes social, physical, and life science data. Second, the Massachusetts Open Cloud (MOC) is a computing environment designed from the ground up to promote user control and ﬂexibility over trust decisions. Third, Conclave compiles legacy code into a cryptographically secure multi-party computation program that can be executed on top of existing data processing frameworks like Hadoop and Spark. This project develops and open-sources the necessary cyberinfrastructure to integrate these technologies and provide a combined "secure computing element" into which data and analytics may be inserted and their resulting answers fed back. This secure computing element incorporates several designs: (i) policy-agnostic programming to ensure that legacy code may be accepted, (ii) the MOC's isolation mechanism to ensure that data owners may choose exactly which environment to entrust with their data, (iii) Conclave to hide the source data from everyone other the intended recipient (even the cloud itself), a policy engine to ensure that the data owner consents to the requested analytic, (iv) Dataverse's data classification engine to manage access control over source and derived data, and (v) a new auditing and billing mechanism to promote transparency, punish those who exceed their privileges, and provide a sustainable economic model for growth.

por.por_cntn:
Two common beliefs in data science are that (1) data scientists must have access to a data repository in order to analyze it and (2) institutions must share data in order to collaborate. These beliefs can hinder research, because data scientists may restrict their research questions based on access to data and potential data contributors may decide on privacy grounds not to volunteer their data for a study. Moreover, these beliefs are false: with modern cryptography, a data scientist can compute aggregate statistics from multiple private datasets without the raw data itself being revealed during the computation. However, cryptographically protected computing is often too slow, expensive, or difficult to use in practice.

The researchers on this Cybersecurity Innovation for Cyberinfrastructure project have developed an open-source software framework that streamlines and automates all aspects of cryptographically protected computing. This framework allows contributors to upload data to the popular Dataverse repository (https://dataverse.harvard.edu), and it seamlessly protects this data in transit, at rest, and in use while executing queries. When a data scientist submits a query, the framework “splits” the calculation between multiple cloud providers on the Mass Open Cloud (https://massopen.cloud) such that they can collectively answer the analyst’s query, but no individual cloud provider learns any data. The framework also empowers data privacy officers at the contributor institutions to specify a policy that limits how analysts can use their data.

Additionally, the researchers have published eight peer-reviewed papers in database and systems security conferences. These works designed, developed, and analyzed new techniques for cryptographically protected computing that (1) scale to handle big data within a datacenter, (2) achieve faster performance due to hardware acceleration, or (3) are easy to use on the web. The first category of research innovations directly impacted the design of our software framework, and the other two categories of publications included early-stage prototypes that can influence future cybersecurity innovations for cyberinfrastructure. Thanks to the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program, the researchers mentored several undergraduate students who participated materially in conducting peer-reviewed scientific research and contributing toward our collaborative software engineering effort.

The framework directly impacts current and future users of Dataverse and the Mass Open Cloud, by allowing them to break down data silos and collaborate across institutions while respecting privacy concerns. To demonstrate the power of cryptographically protected computing, the researchers collaborated with Boston Children’s Hospital and Red Hat to design a prototype system that allows doctors to compare a patient’s health records with other patients in the same demographic to identify any significant deviations from the mean. This demonstration was featured in a keynote talk at the 2019 Red Hat Summit.
